With regard to these conditions, first, we have found high levels of concentration in the one-stop grocery market which would be intensified following the acquisition of Safeway by any of Asda, Morrisons, Sainsbury’s and Tesco and which would facilitate unilateral or coordinated effects. Allowing for current trends in performance, the acquisition of Safeway by Asda would see Asda and Tesco having very substantial market shares, with Sainsbury’s considerably behind and Morrisons remaining very much smaller and only regionally based. The acquisition of Safeway by Morrisons would largely preserve the current structure of national players, but would consolidate the position of the fourth player, and remove any regional-sized player. The acquisition of Safeway by Sainsbury’s would consolidate the position of the three largest players, with no fourth national player; whilst an acquisition by Tesco would give it a market share approaching the size of the next three players taken together.

While the Sainsbury’s/Asda merger might look good on paper,
we see no chance of it getting through the CMA without a major
dismemberment of the combined business. This will only be
possible if there is an acquirer for a significant proportion of the
business and Morrisons is the only acquirer that makes sense.
This would take the big 4 down to 3, which looks highly
unlikely to get through the CMA.
It seems particularly surprising that the management team that
prevaricated about the NISA acquisition and decided not to
proceed due to concerns on getting it through the CMA. This
will be a key merger for incoming CMA boss Andrew Tyrie to
assess, which makes reading the CMA a bit harder.

Local market shares will be even more important and there are plenty of Sainsbury’s trading in close proximity to an Asda.

We would expect a large number to have to be disposed into a market with a limited number of buyers. The stores to be disposed are likely to be too large for a discounter or the Co-op, and M&S and Waitrose are unlikely to want to expand aggressively. Morrisons is the obvious buyer, but they would also have local market concerns and it would not alter the overall concentration. Tesco would struggle to get any more than a handful through the CMA.

We see two main drivers for synergies – improved purchasing
conditions and optimization of head office costs. The new group is targeting £500m in net synergies at the EBITDA level, i.e. 1.1% of combined sales, consistent with Ahold/Delhaize’s target for the US (c. 1%). In terms of regulations, there is no doubt that this merger will be closely scrutinised by the UK competition authorities, but we see limited risk of outright rejection given the powerful presence of hard discounters in the UK. That said, we could see some store disposals. As regards execution risks, investors need to keep in mind the many disappointments we have had in the past with major mergers in the sector due to disruptions (think Morrisons/Safeway and Carrefour/Promodes). The best way to limit execution risk in our view would be to stick to the existing banners.

BE11:24am

So .......... I guess we need to look at the sector response to this deal that won't happen.

When looking at the attractiveness of the overall UK food retail industry from an investor perspective, a reduction from four major players to three would likely be seen as a positive development. (Of course, this is precisely why a merger would likely be scrutinized in great detail by the relevant authorities.) Having said this, if the ASDA and Sainsbury banners kept their individual pricing then this might be seen as “4 players to 3.5” rather than “4 to 3”. The other reason why a merger might be seen as a positive development is that it might mean a modest reduction in industry capacity. In general we would expect the authorities to force stores to be sold to other food retailers rather than be shut, but if there are no food retailers interested then perhaps some stores could be shut or sold to other retailers that are not grocery specialists – resulting in capacity reduction. Overall we would see a Sainsbury/ASDA merger as a positive for the attractiveness of the UK food retail sector as a whole.

#REF! @Helen78 in that both have declining bricks and mortar clothing units?

11:35 am
BE11:36am

The first point is that Morrison would suddenly become a distant number three player – only a third the size of the number one and number two players – whereas it is currently two-thirds the size of number two and number three. Moreover – short of new entrants to the UK market – it is difficult to see what options would be open to Morrison to get back on ‘level pegging’. The positive for Morrison would be that it might be in a very strong position to take advantage of cheap store acquisitions – more so than Tesco because its smaller size would likely mean it would less often be conflicted by its existing store network. In general we would see a Sainsbury/ASDA merger as a clear negative for Morrison in isolation – because of its now-clear size disadvantage – but when combined with the positives for the overall industry, on balance we see it as arguably slightly negative to neutral.

WPP’s 1Q results are a lot better than feared and we expect some
relief this morning. -0.1% organic growth in the 1Q suggests February and March saw the group move back into positive growth territory and, had the group not been encumbered by market research, the quarter as a whole would have been positive in organic terms. Clearly ‘one swallow does not make a spring’ but this is a much more benign context for the executive chairman (Roberto Quarta) and the joint COOs (Mark Read and Andrew Scott) to make their first pronouncements on strategy. We expect perhaps more acknowledgement of structural pressures on the group, but also a more proactive approach to portfolio management as a way of dealing with them. With valuation at less than 10x 2018E P/E, we think upside to the multiple offsets any risk to earnings from (asset disposal related) dilution. Buy WPP.

BE11:53am

Last week started with state-owned miner, Gecamines, seeking the dissolution of KCC and ended with Gertler’s $3bn damages claim. All at a time when Glencore and a consortium of international mining companies operating in the DRC, are attempting to negotiate the softening of key provisions of the country’s new mining code. The timing of these events appear more than coincidental and seem designed to place Glencore under maximum pressure as it seeks to safeguard its substantial investments in the country. In the near term, the greatest risk is to working capital at the two operations, which could be squeezed, leading to a curtailment of production. We expect Katanga and Mutanda to generate ~9% of Glencore’s EBITDA in 2018.

Not as bad as it seems We reduce our recommendation from Top Pick to Outperform on rising uncertainty from these recent developments, however our analysis within suggests at a post-DRC 5.1x EV/EBITDA, and inline with sector peers, a worst case scenario of zero value for the DRC would still leave Glencore shares inexpensive in our view. Our numbers importantly do not include any impact from higher copper prices. Without the DRC, we would expect a premium rating could return to Glencore as its marketing business provides lower earnings volatility. Our target price moves to 410p from 460p.

BE11:55am

The more interesting stuff in there is on the wider impact .....

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Assuming Glencore's DRC assets halt production, the impact on the copper market is likely to be large . Our analysis suggests the lost 360kt of copper will shift the copper market into deficit for 2018. After stripping out the DRC from Glencore we calculate that a $0.25/lb move in the copper price would increase EBITDA by $700m, offsetting nearly half of the DRC impact in our worse case scenario. Glencore's DRC production accounts for 28% of our global cobalt forecast for 2018. The implications to this market would likely be very significant.

BE12:00pm

Here's Stifel to shed some light for us.

BE12:00pm

The group's near-term future is secure at a significant price. Interserve has access to funding of £834m through to 2021, with the leverage covenant (currently 4.4x) starting at 6.5x before falling to 4x over the course of the funding, providing management with time to reduce leverage. In return, interest costs are high (2018: £67m), lenders have exercise warrants worth up to 20% of the post-issue share capital and can convert their debt to equity for up to 20% of the value of any equity fund raising. The contract and balance review has been completed with £162.8m non-underlying items, and positively there is no further EfW provision at this juncture. Whilst we view this as a broadly positive result considering where the group found itself, the group's weak underlying performance demonstrates the challenges management will have in turning round the business through the Fit for Growth programme. We await to see how management tackles structurally high net debt over the medium term.
